NSC100.name: Drew Freshman Seminar
NSC100.description: Academic and non-academic skills and strategies for successful college transition.
NSC100.prerequisite: (MTH 1825 or concurrently) or (MTH 116 or concurrently) or (MTH 132 or concurrently)

NSC102.name: Preprofessional Freshman Seminar
NSC102.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
NSC102.description: Overview of human health care professions with emphasis on academic and nonacademic undergraduate preparation, campus resources, communication and computer skills, and collaborative learning.
NSC102.restrictions: Open to freshmen in the Predental Major or in the Premedical Major or in the Preoptometry Major or approval of department.

NSC104.name: Freshman Seminar Away in Natural Sciences
NSC104.description: Introduction to scientific scholarship and academic inquiry via an intensive empirical learning experience. Strategies for academic success in science and enhancing the college experience.
NSC104.restrictions: Open to freshmen in the College of Natural Science. Approval of college.

NSC192.name: Environmental Issues Seminar
NSC192.description: Environmental issues and problems explored from a variety of perspectives, including legal, scientific, historical, political, socio-economic, and technical points of view.
NSC192.restrictions: Open to students in the College of Communication Arts and Sciences or in the College of Engineering or in the College of Natural Science or in the College of Social Science. Approval of college.

NSC200.name: Drew Sophomore Seminar
NSC200.description: Career exploration and preparation through service-learning experience.

NSC203.name: Drew Laboratory Directed Studies
NSC203.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
NSC203.description: Using topics related to a faculty member's ongoing research, students explore the relationship between science and technology and social issues.
NSC203.restrictions: Open to students in the Charles Drew Science Enrichment Laboratory.

NSC292.name: Applications in Environmental Studies
NSC292.description: Community engagement project. Projects vary depending on student's major and area of environmental interest.
NSC292.restrictions: Open to students in the Environmental Studies Specialization.

NSC390.name: Special Problems
NSC390.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
NSC390.description: Faculty directed individualized study of an interdisciplinary problem.

NSC475.name: International Field Studies in Natural Science
NSC475.description: Contemporary issues in environmental, geological, biological or human health-related sciences of a specific study abroad location.

NSC476.name: Natural Science Field Studies in Selected U.S.A. Locations
NSC476.description: Contemporary issues in environmental, geological, biological or human health-related sciences of a selected domestic study away location.

NSC490.name: Special Problems
NSC490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
NSC490.description: Faculty directed individualized study of an interdisciplinary problem.

NSC491.name: Selected Topics
NSC491.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
NSC491.description: Selected interdisciplinary topics not normally covered in other courses.

NSC493.name: Internships in Natural Science
NSC493.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
NSC493.description: Educational employment experience applying scientific and or research training in industry government and non-profit.
NSC493.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
NSC493.restrictions: Open to sophomores or juniors or seniors in the College of Natural Science. Approval of college; application required.

NSC495.name: Capstone in Human Biology (W)
NSC495.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
NSC495.description: Integration of human biology disciplines with a focus on health and disease.
NSC495.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I writing requirement.
NSC495.restrictions: Open to seniors in the Human Biology Major.

NSC496.name: Directed Study in Human Biology
NSC496.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
NSC496.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I writing requirement.

NSC497.name: Internship in Human Biology
NSC497.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
NSC497.description: Practical experience applying human biology training outside the classroom setting.
NSC497.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I writing requirement.

NSC498.name: Research in Human Biology
NSC498.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
NSC498.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I writing requirement.

NSC499.name: Research
NSC499.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
NSC499.description: Research in faculty laboratories. Oral and written presentations.
NSC499.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the College of Natural Science.

NSC810.name: Biological Science Transmission Electron Microscopy Laboratory
NSC810.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
NSC810.description: Use of transmission microscope and preparative equipment in the biological sciences. Sample preparation techniques. Sectioning for electron microscopy.

NSC815.name: Physical Science Transmission Electron Microscopy Laboratory
NSC815.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
NSC815.description: Experimental methods for transmission electron microscopy in the physical sciences, including digital photography, imaging, diffraction, and microanalysis.

NSC816.name: Advanced Physical Science Transmission Electron Microscopy Laboratory
NSC816.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
NSC816.description: Advanced experimental methods of transmission electron microscopy for the physical sciences. Bright field-dark field imaging. High resolution transmission electron microscope imaging. Nano beam diffraction and convergent beam diffraction. Scanning transmission electron microscope imaging, energy filtered transmission electron microscope imaging, and electron energy loss spectroscopy.

NSC820.name: Scanning Electron Microscopy; Energy Dispersive X-ray Microanalysis
NSC820.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
NSC820.description: Use of scanning electron microscope and energy dispersive x-ray microanalysis. Machine variables, artifacts, quantitative analysis, specimen preparation, darkroom procedures.

NSC825.name: Special Problems in Microscopy
NSC825.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
NSC825.description: Use of microscopy techniques for selected research topics.

NSC837.name: Confocal Microscopy
NSC837.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of odd years
NSC837.description: Confocal imaging, theory and practice. Optics, lasers, light paths for transmission, florescence and reflection imaging. Advanced techniques including Fluorescence recovery after photobleaching (FRAP), Förster resonance energy transfer (FRET), spectral imaging, laser capture and two-photon microscopy.
